title: Terminology
text: Carbon Fertilization Effects: refer to the phenomenon where elevated concentrations of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the atmosphere stimulate plant growth and increase photosynthesis. This effect is based on the role of CO2 as a critical substrate in the process of photosynthesis, which plants use to produce energy and biomass.

title: Terminology
text:
Plants Related

Leaf area index (LAI): one-sided green leaf area per unit ground area
Fraction of absorbed photosynthetic active radiation (FAPAR): fraction of photosynthetic active radiation (0.4–0.7um) absorbed by the vegetation
Solar-induced chlorophyll fluorescence (SIF) is a faint light emitted by chlorophyll molecules during photosynthesis.

title: Terminology
text:
Remote Sensing

Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) first introduced by Rousie and his colleagues in “Monitoring Vegetation Systems in the Great Plains with ERTS”, defined as \[NDVI = (NIR-RED)/(NIR+RED) = [\rho(0.86\mu m)-\rho(0.66\mu m)] / [\rho(0.86\mu m)+\rho(0.66\mu m)]\], where \(\rho\) represents the radiance in reflectance units. Vegetation reflects a high amount of NIR (40-60%), absorbs RED (thus reflect less, below 10%) due to chlorophyll. Thus, healthy vegetation has higher NDVI due to high NIR-to-red ratio. Normalization is essential in NDVI to minimize the effects of lighting conditions, sun angle, and atmospheric interference, making vegetation measurements more consistent and comparable across different times and locations. Consider what will happen during a cloudy day vs. sunny day?
Normalized Difference Water Index (NDWI) introduced by Gao in 1996, defined as \[NDWI = (NIR-SWIR)/(NIR+SWIR) = [\rho(0.86\mu m)-\rho(1.24\mu m)] / [\rho(0.86\mu m)+\rho(1.24\mu m)]\]. Absorption by vegetation liquid water near \(0.86\mu m\) is negligible and weak liquid absorption at \(1.24\mu m\).

title: Terminology
text:
Radiation Related
PAR (photosynthetic active radiation), 400-700 nm, and it is described as the type of light required for photosynthesis.
PPF (Photosynthetic photon flux, µMol/S), how much PAR is being produced by any one lighting system over the period of a second.
PPFD (Photosynthetic photon flux density, µMol/m2/S), how many PAR photons are landing on a specific area.

2024/11/23 Notes About Soil Respiration
Soil Respiration components: root respiration, surface-litter respiration and the respiration of soil organic matter (including root detritus)

Lowest soil respiration occur in coldest (tundra & northern bogs) and driest (deserts) biomes, highest in tropical moist forests where both T and moisture availability are high year-round

Soil respiration rates in northern peatlands were shown to be positively correlated with depth to water table by Moore and Knowles (1989) and Luken and Billings (1985)

Soil respiration rates are positively correlated with mean annual air T and mean annual precipitation

For soil respiration studies Q10 values cited range from 1.3 to 3.3 (Reich & Schlesinger 1992). Based on a review of in situ measurements, the Q10 value for total soil respiration has a median value of 2.4.
The turnover time of soil carbon refers to the average time that carbon remains in the soil before being released back into the atmosphere as carbon dioxide through decomposition. = soil carbon pool / soil respiration rate from the decomposition of soil organic matter (if with assumption live root contribute 30%, then you get soil R * 0.70 for soil organic matter decomposition)

title: Let’s Talk C Here
text:
Researchers developed three ways for predicting global GPP!

Dynamic global vegetation models (DGVMs)
Methods: Compute GPP based on complex process-based algorithms
Benefits: lalala
Limitations:

Underestimate the effect of atmospheric dryness on GPP and overestimate the current increase in GPP

Flux-data driven models
Methods: Eddy-covariance flux measurements
Benefits:
Limitations:
Remote-sensing based models (RSMs)
Methods: Use algorithms based on satellite retrievals of land-surface properties
\[GPP = LUE\times PAR\times fAPAR \]
LUE is light use efficiency, PAR is incident photosynthetically active radiation and fAPAR is the fraction of photosynthetically available radiation absorbed by vegetation
Benefits: Compared to DGVMs, fewer assumptions about vegetation dynamic and productivity
Comapred to flux-data driven models, more extensive data
Limitations:

Validity of RSM-based are challenging due to lack of independent, global-scale empirical data on GPP

title: C Models
text:
2024/11/09 , check the paper here: doi: https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-024-53949-0
Main Research Question:Previous studies found large GPP data-model discrepencies for tropical forests between flux towers and models and here to investigate into the causes of discrepancy. In this study, we found that the data-model discrepancy was due to fAPAR and photosynthetic capacity.
Objective 1 - Compare the biometric GPP to multiple models and satellite-based products, to quantify the data-model discrepancy Implement three study sites with three major forest types. At each site, biometric measured GPP exceeds methods GPP and global GPP products. DGVM > FLUXCOM > MODIS
Objective 2 - Investigate whether the field-observed high productivity is consistent with the leaf photosynthetic traits and other field measurements that were commonly simulated by models discrepency but within the uncertainty range, objective 3 is more important to note it
Objective 3 - Account for the data-model discrepancy of MODIS and Pmodel and explore key responsible parameters in DGVMs, with following 4 hypotheses based on Large data-model discrepancy for GPP could stem from inaccuracies in one or more of these key input variables
Hypothesis 1 - incorrect LUE, or photosynthetic capacity PPFD could not explain the underestimation of GPP at the study sites
Hypothesis 2 - incorrect fAPAR [Accepted] GPP is substantially underestimated when in situ fAPAR is replaced with MODIS fAPAR (A further investigation into MODIS fAPAR shows that during the rainy season, MODIS fAPAR decreases along with increasing cloud cover (up to 90% of pixels), whereas field fAPAR remains fairly constant during the year)
Hypothesis 3 - inappropriate assignments of plant functional types [Rejected] Given ‘forest-only’ GPP of TRENDY and MODIS are much lower than biometric GPP, conclude that the GPP data-model discrepancy between TRENDY and biometric GPP cannot be explained by scaling or PFT issues
Hypothesis 4 - climate variable [Rejected] The data-model differences found for T, RH, PPFD were too small to explain the GPP data-model discrepency, thus rejecting hypothesis 4

title: EC Partitioning
text:
The CO2 analyzer is measuring CO2 flux or what we called net ecosystem exchange (FCO2 or NEE), it’s essentially a difference between ecosystem respiration (Reco) and gross primary production (GPP), as \(NEE = Reco - GPP\). Partitioning is to partition the NEE measured by tower into GPP and Reco, which is important in flux data analysis (Burba, 2022).
There are mainly two groups of NEE partitioning: one group methods are empirical models (establish site specifics relationship between nighttime flux and biophysical controls, then used the relationship to approximate daytime Reco). Another group of methods is more complex but less empirical models (light response curves using just daytime or 24-hour data) (Burba, 2022).
https://www.bgc-jena.mpg.de/5624848/Flux-partitioning
Other Possible Ways on measuring Reco:
1) Estimates from biogeochemical or soil–vegetation–atmosphere transfer (SVAT) models (https://link.springer.com/article/10.1023/A:1002497616547)
2) From chamber measurements extrapolated to the stand scale (https://doi.org/10.1046/j.1365-2486.1999.00214.x; https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11262922/)
Nighttime Partitioning Drawbacks:
1) frequent nighttime suppression of turbulence and dominance of advective fluxes not measured by conventional EC systems (Lasslop et al., 2010)

section: On the temperature dependence of soil respiration (Lloyd & Taylor, 1994) - Nighttime Partitioning
text:
On the temperature dependence of soil respiration (Lloyd & Taylor, 1994) - Nighttime Partitioning
From 2024/11/01 to , check the paper
Research Qs:

Rx​ reflects the baseline respiration rate that is influenced by ecosystem factors like MMM.
f(T) captures the temperature sensitivity in a generalized form that applies across datasets.

1884 Van’t Hoff derivative of the natural logarithm of the reaction rate constant (lnk) with respect to temperature (T). Van’t Hoff observed that the rate of chemical reactions changes exponentially with temperature. And the derivative of it in linear relationship. \[\frac{d(\ln k)}{dT} = \frac{E}{\mathcal{R}T^2} + c\]
1889 Arrhenius built on van’t Hoff’s observations and incorporated the concept of energy distribution among reacting molecules (based on Boltzmann’s statistical mechanics). He simplified van’t Hoff’s equation by assuming c=0 and integrating it into a simpler form to explain reaction kinetics.
\[k = d e^{-\frac{E}{\mathcal{R}T}}\]
Where d is a constant, E is activation energy, T is the absolute temperature (K). But we would like to involve a reference temperature (283.15K), where standardize the temperature dependencies (enables consistent comparisons across data sets, standardizing variation between ecosystems).
\[R = R_{10} e^{\frac{E}{\mathcal{R} \cdot 283.15} \left(1 - \frac{283.15}{T}\right)}\]
Soil respiration involves changing populations of many different organisms, each undergoing a complex series of reactions, which is likely that the activation energies may indeed increase with decreasing temperature. Kavanau (1951) utilized kinetic theory to derive a semi-empirical formulation that effectively gives a decrease in activation energy with increasing temperature.
\[k_R = P \left[1 - e^{-\frac{E_0}{T - T_0}}\right]\]
A simplified version:
\[
R = A e^{-\frac{E_0}{T - T_0}}
\]
Final form relative to 10 celsius degree by Lloyd & Taylor, 1994:
\[R_{\text{eco}}(T) = R_{\text{eco,ref}} e^{E_0 \left( \frac{1}{T_{\text{Ref}} - T_0} - \frac{1}{T - T_0} \right)}\]
This equation indeed used to calculate Reco at night for nighttime partitioning method.
1898 Q10: Van’t Hoff in 1898 (p226-228) observed from the data he collected for T (temperature) vs k (reaction rate constant), for many chemical reactions, the k typically increases by a factor of 2 to 3 for every 10°C increase in temperature [T VS. Reaction Rates]. This is in exponential relationship. To further test if reaction rates are in certain times for 10°C intervals, we used: \(log_{10}k = a +bt\) & \((k_{t+10})/k_t = 10^{10b}\)
This make us available to calculate any ratios, such as for ethyl acetate: 9.4°C k=2.307 & 44.94°C k=21.648, sub to \(log_{10}k = a +bt\), we are able to calculate b and then \(10^{10b}\) to get the ratios.
The idea posted by Van’t Hoff was further widely used in ecology study.

title: EC Partitioning
section: On the seperation of net ecosystem exchange into assimilation and ecosystem respiration: review and improved algorithm (Reichstein, 2005)
text:
On the seperation of net ecosystem exchange into assimilation and ecosystem respiration: review and improved algorithm (Reichstein, 2005)
From 2024/11/24 to , check the paper here: doi: 10.1111/j.1365-2486.2005.001002.x
Main Research Question: analyse the effect of short-term vs. long-term temperature sensitivity on the estimation of daytime Reco and GPP.

(The observed seasonal temperature sensitivity of ecosystem respiration includes influences from other factors (e.o., soil moisture, growth) that vary with temperature, making it different from the actual short-term temperature sensitivity.)

Improved Algorithm:

Collect half-hourly eddy covariance flux data, ensuring high-quality night-time data through a turbulence filtering threshold.
Segment the data into 15-day windows, with a 10-day overlap between consecutive windows.
Perform short-term regressions within each window to estimate temperature sensitivity (E0).
Linearly interpolate Rref based on estimates from 4-day periods and integrate E0, short into respiration calculations.
Use the improved algorithm to partition NEE into GEP and Reco while addressing biases from long-term temperature sensitivity.

\[R_{\text{eco}}(T) = R_{\text{eco,ref}} e^{E_0 \left( \frac{1}{T_{\text{Ref}} - T_0} - \frac{1}{T - T_0} \right)}\]
T0 is kept constant at -46.02 celsius degrees; Tref is set to 10 celsius degrees in (Reichstein, 2005) and 15 celsius degrees in (Lasslop et al., 2010). E0, temperature sensitivity is a constant value used for the whole year in (Lasslop et al., 2010) and in a short periods in (Reichstein, 2005), Reco,ref was estimated every 5 days using a 15 days window.
Using daytime temperature, respiration is extrapolated to the daytime and the difference between modeled Reco and measured NEE yields estimated GPP. We refer to this estimate as ‘NB’ (nighttime data-based).
The paper for REddyProc package: https://bg.copernicus.org/articles/15/5015/2018/

title: EC Partitioning
section: Daytime flux partitioning method -> Lasslop et al. (2010)
text:
Daytime flux partitioning method -> Lasslop et al. (2010)
Daytime flux partitioning method -> Lasslop et al. (2010)
Light–response curves are fit to daytime NEE measurements and respiration is estimated from the intercept of the ordinate, which avoids the use of potentially problematic nighttime data.
Falge et al. (2001)
Biases of nighttime partitioning methods:
Lasslop et al. (2010)
Methods that rely on nighttime data for partitioning may be biased due to the frequent nighttime suppression of turbulence and dominance of advective fluxes not measured by conventional EC systems (Goulden et al., 1996; Aubinet et al., 2000; Feigenwinter et al., 2004; Aubinet, 2008).
Daytime data-based estimate including temperature sensitivity of respiration.
(Michaelis and Menten, 1913) examines the concentration of sucrose affects the rate of its enzymatic inversion, models how reaction velocity (rate of product formation) depends on the substrate concentration. Which expresses reaction rate as a hyperbolic function:
\[v = \frac{V_{\text{max}}[S]}{K_m + [S]}\]
where \(V_{max}\)​ is the maximum rate, [S] is the substrate concentration, and \(K_m\)​ is the Michaelis constant (substrate concentration at half-maximum rate).
Rectangular hyperbolic light-response curve (Falge et al., 2001)
\[\begin{equation}\mathrm{NEE} = \frac{\alpha \beta R_g}{\alpha R_g + \beta} + \gamma\end{equation}\]
\(\alpha \, (\mu\text{mol C J}^{-1})\) is the canopy light utilization efficiency and represents the initial slope of the light–response curve
\(\beta \, (\mu\text{mol C m}^{-2} \text{s}^{-1})\) is the maximum CO2 uptake rate of the canopy at light saturation
\(\gamma \, (\mu\text{mol C m}^{-2} \text{s}^{-1})\) is the ecosystem respiration
\(R_g \, ({W m}^{-2})\) is the global radiation
Gilmanov et al. (2003) consider the temperature sensitivity of the Reco, thus combined with Llyod & Taylor (1994), then:
\[\begin{equation}\mathrm{NEE} = \frac{\alpha \beta R_g}{\alpha R_g + \beta} + R_{\text{eco,ref}} e^{E_0 \left( \frac{1}{T_{\text{Ref}} - T_0} - \frac{1}{T - T_0} \right)}\end{equation}\]
There are two ways in estimating parameters:
a) E0 was estimated using nighttime data, Reco,ref, alpha, beta were derived from daytime data ; b) All parameters were estimated using daytime data.
With the consideration of VPD limitation, β could be further interpreted as with an exponential decreasing function (Korner, 1995)
\[
\beta =\begin{cases} \beta_0 \exp(-k(\text{VPD} - \text{VPD}_0)), & \text{VPD} > \text{VPD}_0, \\\beta_0, & \text{VPD} \leq \text{VPD}_0.\end{cases}
\]

title: EC Partitioning
section: Widespread inhibition of daytime ecosystem respiration (Keenan et al., 2019)
text:
Widespread inhibition of daytime ecosystem respiration (Keenan et al., 2019)
https://www.nature.com/articles/s41559-019-0809-2#ref-CR12 With the consideration of the inhibition of leaf respiration in the light
The daytime and nighttime approaches are built on the assumption that the reference respiration rate (Rref) does not change between night and day. If there’s inhibition of leaf respiration in the light, then nighttime method will overestimate daytime respiration and the daytime method will underestimate the nighttime respiration
Here, modified both the standard daytime and night-time partitioning methods to account for an apparent inhibition by estimating and applying Rref nighttime and Rref daytime separately.
